Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
South Florida Community College (SFCC) is collaborating with Vercipia Biofuels and other biofuel/biomass companies in Florida's agricultural heartland to address the technician workforce needs of the advanced biofuels industry. The goals of the project are to educate technicians to work in the advanced biofuels production industry and agriculture biomass production; develop instructional materials about advanced biofuels production; and establish a biofuels education pathway from area high schools to South Florida Community College to Florida universities.

To achieve its goals, the Bioenergy Education project is creating (1) Associate of Science degree programs in Biofuels Technology and in Biomass Cultivation, (2) industry-recognized certificate education programs in biofuels technology and biomass production, (3) transfer agreements with Florida universities, (4) continuing education workshops and seminars for biofuel industry professionals, and (5) dual-enrollment biofuels education courses for area high school students interested in biofuels. The evaluation plan is collecting quantitative data on participant enrollment, retention, graduation, transfer, and employment, and qualitative data on participant and employer satisfaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
South Florida State College (SFSC) developed two Associate in Science (A.S.) degree programs, as well as corresponding College Credit Certificate (C.C.C.) Programs, in Biomass Cultivation and in Biofuels Technology to prepare technicians for the advanced biofuels industry in Florida. These programs are among the first of its kind in the state, focusing on the biomass production and biorefinery, Since 2014, SFSC enrollment in these programs have been opened to a large pool of rural, low income students, including dually enrolled high school students from DeSoto, Hardee and Highlands Counties. In addition, SFSC delivered bioenergy-related education materials to aspiring high schools through a week long summer STEM program called AgDiscovery in June 2016. The AgDiscovery program focused on exploring educational and career opportunities in the bioenergy and agriculture industries and provided students with hands-on laboratory experiments related to bioprocessing, biofuel production, pollution control, wastewater and solid waste management, and environmental biotechnology, Non-credit seeking individuals also benefited from SFSC's Bioenergy Education Program through participation at the Biomass Feedstock Production in Florida's Heartland Conference in April 2016. The conference included presentations from academic researchers and industry professionals on how to cultivate a wide range of feedstocks (e.g., industrial sugar crops, oilseeds, algae, and woody biomass) and how to produce a wide range of biogas and liquid biofuels. At the completion of the grant, a total of 81 individuals received training through the A.S. and C.C.C. degree programs, summer STEM AgDiscovery program, and Biomass Feedstock Production in Florida's Heartland Conference of SFSC's Bioenergy Education Program.
